section.name: Intercepting popped-up dialogs and windows
section.p: UISpec4J provides a mechanism for detecting dialog or popups displayed by the application, without requiring any change in the production code. This mechanism relies on the Swing Look&Feel classes, especially those evolving around the Toolkit and Peer interfaces.

The trick is to provide our own Toolkit implementation, which instantiates Peer components that intercept calls to dialog and popup "show()" methods and trigger the UISpec4J code instead of displaying them on the screen.

In order to enable the interception mechanism, you will need to call the UISpec4J.init() method before any Swing component gets instanciated - if init() is called too late, the Swing default toolkit will have already been set up and the interception will not work.

subsection.name: Intercepting modal dialogs
subsection.p: Modal dialogs are more difficult to handle than their non-modal counterparts, because the application code is blocked while the dialog is being shown, waiting for a result.
To manage this, the WindowInterceptor class provides a means for registering a set of handlers that will be executed within the context of the dialog:

This approach involves three steps:
The interception is started with a Trigger. As for non-modal windows, it is responsible for triggering the display of the dialog.
The WindowHandler provided to the WindowInterceptor.process() method is given the shown window in its process() call. The body of this method is responsible for dealing with that window, and then returning a trigger that will close it. In our example we return a trigger that will click on the "OK" button displayed in the dialog.
The interception is actually started only when the run() method is called.

subsection.name: Built-in window handlers
subsection.p: The WindowInterceptor class provides a number of utility methods for handling dialogs with a simple button click, or just waiting for a transient progress window to close itself. Please refer to the Javadoc of this class for more information.
A specific WindowHandler implementation is available for file choosers: the FileChooserHandler class. Please refer to the Javadoc of this class for more information.

subsection.name: Custom window handlers
subsection.p: In order to keep your tests as simple as possible, we suggest that you develop your own window handler classes for the most frequently used dialogs in your application. This will avoid a proliferation of complex inner class definitions in your tests, and keep your test code more compact.
